q: Who was the first Governor-General of Bengal?
desc: Warren Hastings served as the first Governor-General of Bengal from 1774 to 1785.

q: Which act brought an end to the dual government system?
desc: The Regulating Act of 1773, implemented by Warren Hastings, ended the dual government system.

q: What was the significance of the Act of 1781?
pool: Demarcated jurisdiction between Governor-General and Supreme Court
answer: Demarcated jurisdiction between Governor-General and Supreme Court
desc: The Act of 1781 clarified the roles of the Governor-General-in-Council and the Supreme Court at Calcutta.

q: Which act was passed in 1784 to improve governance in India?
desc: Pitt’s India Act of 1784 was enacted to address the shortcomings of the Regulating Act of 1773.

q: The Rohilla War occurred during the term of which Governor-General?
desc: The Rohilla War of 1774 occurred under Warren Hastings.

q: When was the First Maratha War fought?
desc: The First Maratha War took place from 1775 to 1782 under Warren Hastings.

q: Which treaty ended the First Maratha War?
desc: The Treaty of Salbai (1782) brought the First Maratha War to an end.

q: The Second Mysore War took place during the tenure of which Governor-General?
desc: The Second Mysore War (1780–84) occurred during Warren Hastings' administration.

q: Who founded the Asiatic Society of Bengal?
desc: Sir William Jones founded the Asiatic Society of Bengal in 1784 in Calcutta.

q: In which year was the English translation of Bhagavad Gita published?
desc: Charles Wilkins translated the Bhagavad Gita into English in 1785.

q: Who translated the Bhagavad Gita into English?
desc: Charles Wilkins translated the Bhagavad Gita into English in 1785.

q: Which war did Lord Cornwallis fight against Tipu Sultan?
desc: Lord Cornwallis led the British in the Third Mysore War (1790–92) against Tipu Sultan.

q: Which treaty ended the Third Mysore War?
desc: The Treaty of Seringapatnam (1792) concluded the Third Mysore War.

q: Who introduced the Permanent Settlement in Bengal?
desc: Lord Cornwallis introduced the Permanent Settlement system in 1793 in Bengal and Bihar.

q: When was the Permanent Settlement introduced?
desc: The Permanent Settlement was implemented in 1793 under Lord Cornwallis.

q: Who is known as the Father of Civil Services in India?
desc: Lord Cornwallis is regarded as the Father of Civil Services in India for initiating administrative reforms.

q: What administrative reform did Cornwallis introduce?
pool: Separation of revenue and judicial functions
answer: Separation of revenue and judicial functions
desc: Cornwallis introduced judicial reforms by separating revenue and judicial administration.

q: What was a key feature of Cornwallis' policing reforms?
desc: Cornwallis introduced a policing system with circles (thanas) headed by Indian officials called Darogas.

q: Who translated Abhigyan Shakuntalam into English?
desc: William Jones translated Kalidasa’s *Abhigyan Shakuntalam* into English in 1789.

q: In which year was Abhigyan Shakuntalam translated into English?
desc: William Jones translated *Abhigyan Shakuntalam* into English in 1789.

q: Who succeeded Cornwallis as Governor-General of Bengal?
desc: Sir John Shore succeeded Lord Cornwallis in 1793.

q: Which Governor-General played a key role in the Permanent Settlement?
desc: Sir John Shore supported and helped implement the Permanent Settlement system.

q: The Battle of Kharda took place in which year?
desc: The Battle of Kharda was fought in 1795 between the Marathas and the Nizam of Hyderabad.

q: Which two powers were involved in the Battle of Kharda?
desc: The Battle of Kharda (1795) was fought between the Nizam of Hyderabad and the Marathas.

q: What was the role of Sir John Shore in the Battle of Kharda?
desc: Sir John Shore remained neutral during the Battle of Kharda, declining military help to the Nizam.

q: Who was Governor-General when the Treaty of Salbai was signed?
desc: The Treaty of Salbai (1782) was signed during Warren Hastings’ tenure.

q: The Asiatic Society of Bengal was founded in which city?
desc: The Asiatic Society of Bengal was established in Calcutta in 1784.

q: The term 'Father of Civil Services in India' refers to which Governor-General?
desc: Lord Cornwallis earned this title due to his foundational reforms in Indian civil administration.

q: Which Governor-General's tenure saw both the Third Mysore War and Permanent Settlement?
desc: Lord Cornwallis was responsible for conducting the Third Mysore War and implementing the Permanent Settlement.

q: Who introduced the Subsidiary Alliance in India?
desc: The Subsidiary Alliance system was introduced by Lord Wellesley in 1798.

q: Which Indian ruler was the first to accept the Subsidiary Alliance?
desc: The Nizam of Hyderabad was the first to sign the Subsidiary Alliance in 1798.

q: Which of these states did NOT enter into Subsidiary Alliance under Lord Wellesley?
desc: Punjab, under Ranjit Singh, did not enter into the Subsidiary Alliance system under Lord Wellesley.

q: The Treaty of Bassein (1802) was signed with which Indian power?
desc: The Treaty of Bassein was signed in 1802 between the British and the Peshwa Baji Rao II.

q: Which war was a consequence of the Treaty of Bassein?
desc: The Treaty of Bassein led to the Second Maratha War (1803–1805).

q: During whose tenure did the Vellore Mutiny take place?
desc: The Vellore Mutiny occurred in 1806 under Governor-General George Barlow.

q: In which year did the Vellore Mutiny take place?
desc: The Vellore Mutiny occurred in 1806 due to religious and cultural grievances.

q: Who signed the Treaty of Amritsar with Maharaja Ranjit Singh?
desc: Lord Minto I signed the Treaty of Amritsar with Ranjit Singh in 1809.

q: The Treaty of Amritsar was signed in which year?
desc: The Treaty of Amritsar was signed in 1809 between the British and Ranjit Singh.

q: Which act ended the trade monopoly of the East India Company?
desc: The Charter Act of 1813 ended the East India Company's monopoly on trade in India (except tea and trade with China).

q: Who was Governor-General when the Charter Act of 1813 was passed?
desc: The Charter Act of 1813 was enacted during the tenure of Lord Minto I.

q: The Anglo-Nepal War was fought during the tenure of which Governor-General?
desc: The Anglo-Nepal War (1814–1816) took place under Lord Hastings.

q: Which treaty ended the Anglo-Nepal War?
desc: The Treaty of Sagauli (1816) ended the Anglo-Nepal War and resulted in the cession of Nepali territory to the British.

q: The Third Maratha War took place during whose tenure?
desc: The Third Maratha War (1817–1818) occurred under Lord Hastings.

q: What was the outcome of the Third Maratha War?
desc: The Third Maratha War ended the Maratha Confederacy and established British supremacy in western India.

q: Which new province was created after the Third Maratha War?
desc: The Bombay Presidency was created following the defeat of the Marathas in the Third Maratha War.

q: The Pindari War was fought during which Governor-General’s term?
desc: The Pindari War (1817–1818) was fought under Lord Hastings to eliminate the Pindari menace.

q: Who introduced the Ryotwari System in Madras Presidency?
desc: Thomas Munro introduced the Ryotwari System in 1820 under Lord Hastings' administration.

q: In which year was the Ryotwari System introduced?
desc: The Ryotwari System was introduced in 1820 by Thomas Munro.

q: During which Governor-General’s tenure was the First Burmese War fought?
desc: The First Burmese War (1824–1826) took place under Lord Amherst.

q: Which treaty ended the First Burmese War?
desc: The Treaty of Yandaboo in 1826 ended the First Burmese War.

q: When was the Treaty of Yandaboo signed?
desc: The Treaty of Yandaboo was signed in 1826, marking the end of the First Burmese War.

q: Which city was captured in 1826 under Lord Amherst?
desc: Bharatpur was captured in 1826 during the tenure of Lord Amherst.

q: Lord Amherst served as Governor-General during which period?
desc: Lord Amherst was the Governor-General of India from 1823 to 1828.

q: Lord Wellesley served as Governor-General during which years?
desc: Lord Wellesley served as the Governor-General of India from 1798 to 1805.

q: Which Governor-General signed treaties with multiple Indian states under the Subsidiary Alliance system?
desc: Lord Wellesley expanded British influence by signing Subsidiary Alliances with various Indian states.

q: Who was the Governor-General during the Third Maratha War and the Pindari War?
desc: Lord Hastings presided over both the Third Maratha War and the Pindari War.

q: Which Governor-General signed a treaty with Maharaja Ranjit Singh?
desc: Lord Minto I signed the Treaty of Amritsar with Ranjit Singh in 1809.

q: The capture of Bharatpur in 1826 happened under which Governor-General?
desc: Bharatpur was captured in 1826 during the administration of Lord Amherst.
